title: AZ--Phoenix-Hiker-Rescues
headline: Phoenix officials reiterate caution when hiking after 3 mountain rescues in 1 day
headline_extended: Phoenix first responders are reminding the public to be prepared when hiking after they tended to three different mountain rescues Saturday morning
description_summary: Phoenix first responders are reminding the public to be prepared when hiking after they tended to three different mountain rescues Saturday morning. The Phoenix Fire Department warned hikers need to make sure they dress appropriately and have plenty of water, even with the city seeing cooler temperatures. People should also make sure they are carrying a cellphone and consider hiking with company. Also, they should also not push themselves if they have health condition such as asthma, diabetes or knee or back pain. Phoenix firefighters had to assist an injured hiker on South Mountain and further north around Camelback Mountain.

body_nitf:
PHOENIX (AP) — Phoenix first responders are reminding the public to be prepared when hiking after they tended to three different mountain rescues on Saturday.

Phoenix firefighters had to assist an injured hiker on a trail on South Mountain. Farther north on Camelback Mountain, a woman suffered a leg injury and had to be airlifted. Also in north Phoenix on Lookout Mountain, a rescue team had to take a hiker to the bottom of a trail on a stretcher due to an injury.

The Phoenix Fire Department warned hikers need to make sure they dress appropriately and have plenty of water, even with the city seeing cooler temperatures.

People should also make sure they are carrying a cellphone and consider hiking with company. Also, they should also not push themselves if they have health condition such as asthma, diabetes or knee or back pain.

Health.reason: The document discusses safety precautions and health considerations for hiking, such as dressing appropriately, staying hydrated, carrying a cellphone, and not pushing oneself if they have health conditions like asthma, diabetes, or knee/back pain. These points are related to maintaining health and preventing injuries while engaging in physical activity. However, the primary focus is on hiking safety rather than broader health topics.
